title: How to Replace a Cricket Bat Grip

steps.title: Remove the old grip.
steps.content: Remove the old grip. This will require strength, as it can be secured quite tightly. If you don't want to keep the old grip, then tear it. Start tearing from lower end. When torn in half, remove the other part of grip by pulling it.

steps.title: Secure the new grip onto the bat cone.
steps.content: Secure the new grip onto the bat cone. Hold the bat cone firmly with one hand. Pass the new grip onto the thin end of the bat cone while pulling it to full extension. Hold the bottom edge of the grip between the thumb and index finger of your other hand. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Roll the grip up the bat cone.
steps.content: Roll the grip up the bat cone. Fold the rubber over itself until it forms an "O" shape. Leave only a small part of the grip unrolled at the top of the cone.

steps.title: Remove the rolled-up grip from the cone.
steps.content: Remove the rolled-up grip from the cone. Pass the grip back on the thin end of the bat cone, with the unrolled portion going on first.

steps.title: Roll the grip to the far end of the bat.
steps.content: Roll the grip to the far end of the bat. Do this step carefully, being sure not to roll or unroll it further. Slip the hollow edge of the bat cone over the butt end of your cricket bat.

steps.title: Push the grip off the cone.
steps.content: Push the grip off the cone. Push it onto the shaft of the bat without unrolling the grip. Do this until it reaches the shoulder of the bat.

steps.title: Pull the top grip taut against the bat.
steps.content: Pull the top grip taut against the bat. You will need to keep it tight so that it doesnâ€™t slip off. Be sure to align it flush against the edge of the shoulder.

steps.title: Unroll the grip.
steps.content: Unroll the grip. Now you are ready to unroll the grip down the handle of the bat using one hand, holding the grip firmly in place at the shoulder with the other hand.

steps.title: Wrap the grip over the butt of the bat.
steps.content: Wrap the grip over the butt of the bat. Cut off any excess grip hanging past the edge with scissors. Excess grip could get in your way while playing, so take your time to do this.

steps.title: Secure the grip in place.
steps.content: Secure the grip in place. Wrap electrical tape around the edge where the grip meets the shoulder to secure it in place. Your bat should now be ready for a game of cricket.

steps.title: Take off the old grip.
steps.content: Take off the old grip. Begin tearing it from its lower end. When the grip has been ripped in half, pull the rest of it off.

steps.title: Buy a new grip.
steps.content: Buy a new grip. New grips tend to be relatively inexpensive. Make sure that it is of good quality so that it will not need to be replaced too often.

steps.title: Hold the bat tightly.
steps.content: Hold the bat tightly. Hold the lower part of the new grip, making sure to hold it so that its handle remains facing upwards.

steps.title: Expand the grip.
steps.content: Expand the grip. Once the bat handle has been fit slightly inside the grip, firmly and slowly force the grip to fit it the rest of the way down the handle. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Test the bat.
steps.content: Test the bat. The work is done, and you will now be ready to play cricket without fear of the bat slipping. Just be sure to change the grip once every three months or so.

steps.title: Buy a grip cone.
steps.content: Buy a grip cone. This should only cost about $3.50, and the cost will end up being worth it, as you should be able to change your grip more easily using a grip cone in the future. [3] X Research source
